all_paragraphs: If you haven’t done a lot of programming, learning R can be pretty intimidating.
But it’s easier if you focus on fundamentals, and slowly build up your skills through practice. Here I’ll give a short lesson on the most basic things you can do in R.
This post is adapted from my online course So You Need to Learn R. It assumes you have a copy of RStudio installed, which is free for individuals.
Let’s start by looking at the very basics of how we enter commands in R, to tell R what we want to do. This is called giving R an expression.
If you open an RStudio session, you’ll see a console with some introductory text, and a prompt (the little > symbol):
You can type commands after that prompt, and R will evaluate them after you hit Return or Enter; that means it will interpret them for meaning and try to compute some kind of result.
To begin with, let’s just use R as a glorified scientific calculator. Enter these commands and hit Enter to get some output:
So R understands numbers and common mathematical operators. This includes multiplication with an asterisk, *, and division with the forward slash, /.
You can compute powers with the caret symbol, ^ (shift-6), for instance to compute four squared. You can do negative numbers too.

R understands decimal notation (whether it’s a . or a , depends on your country; R is typically smart about that). We do not use commas or other thousands separators in large numbers though: that will give us an error.

R also understands and respects the order of operations. Powers come before multiplication, which comes before addition, and so on. Yes, you’ll have to dust off your recollection of high-school math. For operations within the same level, R works from left to right.

You can modify this order with parentheses, just as you would in any othermathematical context. If you want one plus two to be evaluated first, you put it in parentheses and get a quite different answer:

Jasper McChesney is a senior data analyst, with a background in biological science and data visualization. He has worked in non-profits, human-resources, and higher education. He teaches an R course at the University of Massachusetts, and online at Udemy.
